title: Gaura Mandala Parikrama | Srinivasa Acharya: His Birth & Spiritual Legacy | Sri Jai Chaitanya Dasa
speaker: HG Jai Chaitanya Dasa

segments.text: Srinivas Acharya was born in 1530 A.D.
On the full moon day of the month of Vaisakha, in the village of Chakhandi, in the district of Nadia,
his father, Gangadhar Bhattacharya, was a Brahmin of the Rarha class.
The Bhakti Ratnakara describes the event as follows.
When Mahaprabhu took sannyas in Kathua, Gangadhar Bhattacharya was overcome with grief
and began to cry constantly while calling out the names,
Ha Chaitanya, Ha Chaitanya.
When other devotees saw him intoxicated in divine love for Mahaprabhu,
they nicknamed him Chaitanya Das, a name that stuck with him for the rest of his life.
Chaitanya Dasa had no desire for the things of this world.
But one day, he suddenly felt a strong wish to have a son and told this to his wife, Leshmipriya.
She responded by telling him to immediately go to Puri
and ask Mahaprabhu,
for his blessings.
The couple left for Puri, stopping for a few days at the house of Balaram Vibhra,
Leshmipriya's father, in Jaji Gram.
When they arrived in Puri, Chaitanya Dasa and his wife paid their obeisances to Mahaprabhu.
But before they could speak, the Lord himself said,
understanding their desire,
Jagannath Deva will surely fulfill all your desires.
The other devotees said,
The other devotees were curious about what desire Mahaprabhu was talking about,
and they asked his servant Govinda.
But before he could say anything, Mahaprabhu called Govinda and gave him the answer.
Chaitanya Dasa decides to have a son.
Indeed, his wife will give birth to a jewel of a son,
who will be named Srinivas.
He will be the manifest form of my love and will be non-different from me.
He will increase everyone's love.
He will increase everyone's enthusiasm for devotion.
Through Rupa and others, I will bring scriptures into the world,
and through Srinivas, I shall distribute them.
Once they had received Mahaprabhu's blessing,
Chaitanya Dasa and his wife returned to his home,
and when the auspicious moment came, a son was born to them.
Chaitanya Dasa immediately offered the child to Mahaprabhu.

went to visit Narahari Sarkar in nearby Srikanta. From Narahari, he learned that
Mahaprabhu would shortly be ending his earthly pastimes. This news made Srinivas
determined to see the Lord before it happened. He quickly returned to
Jajigram and took permission from his mother to make a trip to Puri. He then
joined the devotees on the annual pilgrimage. It was the fifth day of the
waxing moon. Before arriving in Puri, however, the news arrived that Mahaprabhu
had indeed ended his Leela. Srinivas Acharya fainted at the news and when he
came back to consciousness, he decided to commit suicide. However, the Lord himself
appeared to him in a dream and told him to complete his journey to Puri.
Once in Puri, he again had a dream in which he saw Jagannath, Subhadra,
and Baladev, as well as Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, with his associates. The
incarnation of Mahaprabhu's pleasure potency, Srila Gadhadara Pandit Goswami,
met him and both of them were immersed in an ocean of ecstasy. Srinivas also met
Raya Ramananda, Paramananda Puri, Sakhi Mahayati, Sarvabhauma Bhatt, Sarvabhauma Pandit,
Shikhi Mahayati, Sarvabhauma Pandit, Prakreshwara Pandit, and Srinivas Acharya.
They met Govinda, Shankara Pandit, Gopinath Acharya and received blessings from them all.
Srinivas Acharya stayed for some time in Puri, hearing Srimad Bhagavatam from Gadhadara Pandit
Goswami. Gadhadara then told him to return to Gouda. When Srinivas returned, he heard
that Advaita Acharya and Nityananda Prabhu had also disappeared. Once again, he determined
to end his life. But the two Prabhus appeared to him in a dream
and had him give up his intention. When he arrived in Navadvipa, Srinivas was once again
plunged into a morose of sorrow at the loss of Chaitanya Mahaprabhu. Vamshi Vadanananda
Gotthakur saw him in this condition and approached Vishnupriya Devi and asked her to grant an
audience to Srinivas and bless him. Srinivas Acharya was amazed to see the intense renunciation
and deep faith of Mahaprabhu's widow. While in Navadvipa, he had a dream of Satchi Devi
and received blessings from her too. Srinivas then wandered throughout Bengal, going to
all the three parts of the associates of Mahaprabhu and Nityananda Prabhu, seeking their blessings.
He visited Shantipur, Kardaha, Kanakula, Krishnanagar, Srikanta, etc., met Murari Gupta,
Sivasa Pandit, Damodara Pandit, Shukkaam Brahma Brahmachari, Gadadhar Das, Parameshwari Das,
Jnanava Devi, Vasudha Devi, Veerabhadra, Averam Thakur, Narahari Sarkar Thakur, Raghunandan
Thakur. All these great personalities witnessed Srinivas' intense devotion and told him to
go to Vrindavana. Srinivas then went to his mother and asked her repeatedly for permission
to make the trip to Vrindavan.
which she could not refuse when she saw his great eagerness.
Srinivasa then travelled through Agra, Dvipa, Khatva, Maureshwara, Eka Chakra to Kashi, Ayodhya and Prayag.
He spent a long time travelling and visiting all these holy places before finally arriving at Vraja.
There he heard that Rupa Goswami, Sanatan Goswami, Kashi Shwara Pandit and Raghunath Bhatta Goswami had all disappeared.
Raghunath Das Goswami, Gopalabhatta Goswami and Jeeva Goswami were still living.
However, Srinivas met all three of them and received their blessings.
He was initiated by Gopalabhatta and took instruction in the Vaishnava scriptures from Jeeva.
In great affection for Srinivasa, Jeeva commended him to his deities, Radha Dhamodara.
Srinivasa met Raghunath Das and Krishna Das Kaviraj in Radha Kunda and received their blessings.
One day, Sri Jeeva heard Srinivasa explain a verse from Ujjwala Ninamani and was so impressed by his erudition that he bestowed the title Acharya upon him.
Jeeva also gave the title.
Jeeva gave the title Thakur to Narottama and Shamananda and Shamananda name to Dukkhi Krishna Das.
Jeeva ordered Srinivas to tour the sites of pilgrimages in Braja area with Raghava Goswami.

Sri Jeeva and other Vaishnavas in Braja ordered him, Narottama and Srinivas to take manuscripts of these most remembered scriptures.

truth of the rumors the astrologer confirmed that this was indeed a cargo of great value
the king immediately sent a group of robbers
to steal it, specifying that they should kill no one. The robbers first worshipped the goddess
Chandi, then sent out a spy who returned to tell them that everyone in the group accompanying the
ox-cart was sleeping in exhaustion. After eating their night meal, the robbers thought that this
was surely Chandi's mercy that a golden opportunity like this had come their way.
They seized the ox-cart and the books, thinking they were gold and jewels, and turned them over
to the king. When Vishnupura's king saw the large chest, he was delighted at the prospect of finding
a large amount of valuables inside. How disappointed he must have been to see nothing but books inside.
He turned to the astrologer and asked him how he could have made such a mistake.
The astrologer answered, I cannot understand it. Every time I made my calculation,
it came up with the same conclusion. This chest is full of priceless jewels.
It is incredible. I don't know why my calculations have gone wrong. The mere sight of the holy books
had a purifying effect on the king. This king is King Virahambar of this place. We are in his
kingdom.
Be careful with any valuables you have. However, and he regretted having stolen them. Indeed,
he desired to meet with the acharya of the books. The next morning, Srinivasa, Narottama, and
Shamananda awoke to find the chest of the books missing. They searched everywhere, but when they
failed to find any clue to the books whereabout, they felt so depressed that they considered
killing themselves. Some local villagers saw the distressed condition of the three
Vaishnavas and immediately suspected the robber king Veerahambira. Srinivasa made some
further investigations and was assured that he would be able to find more information
about the king himself. The three Vaishnavas felt some hope and abandoned their suicidal
intentions. Srinivasa Acharya decided to remain in Vishnupura in the hope of finding the books,
but he sent Narottama to Keturi and Shamananda to Orissa.
While staying in Vishnupura, Srinivasa heard from a Brahmin named Krishna Vallabha that
Veerahambira liked to listen to Srimad Bhagavatam and daily attended classes. On the next day,
Srinivasa went with his Brahmin to the hall where the Bhagavata classes were held. The
Brahmin introduced Srinivasa to the king as a great Vaishnava, and the king indeed observed
the characteristics of the Brahmin.
The king expressed a desire to hear Srinivasa speak on the Bhagavata, and Srinivasa agreed,
thinking that this might be a good opportunity to recover the books. So he started to give
lectures on the Bhagavata on a daily basis. The king was enchanted by Srinivasa's unprecedented
explanations of the Bhagavata in his sweet voice.
Srinivasa's acharyas primarily preached Bahan Prabhu's Dharma through speaking on the
Bhagavata and Kirtan, while Narottama and Shamananda primarily used the medium of Kirtan.
The styles of Kirtan that these three acharyas used were named Manohara Sahi, Garana Hati,
and Reneti.

to be given to Srinivasa Acharya.
One day, when he had the opportunity to find the king alone in his apartment, Srinivasa
recounted the entire story of the journey from Raja and the theft of the manuscripts.
The king immediately confessed, showing great sorrow for his misdeed, and had the chest
of books returned to its owner.
In great relief, Srinivasa immediately sent messengers to Vrindavan, Narottama, and Shamananda
with the good news.
In the course of time, Veerahambira and his entire entourage all took initiation from
Srinivasa and dedicated their entire lives and wealth to him.

Srinivasa respected Narahari Sarkar of Shrikhanda greatly and was also very devoted to his saintly mother.
When Narahari heard Srinivasa's mother express her desire to see her son married, he gave him the order to do so.
Even prior to receiving this order, Srinivasa had received the same command from Advaita Acharya in a dream.
Though he felt somewhat ashamed, he realized that he could not ignore the wishes of Narahari.
His mother and Advaita Prabhu, he thus agreed to get married and was wed to Ishwari, the devoted daughter of Gopala Chakravarti of Jajigraha.

Sri Shuklambara Brahmachari, Gadadara Das, Narahari Sarkar and Dujahari Das all ended their earthly activities.
Srinivasa Acharya once again felt overcome by grief and made another trip to Vrindavan.
Once again he met the Gopalbhata and Sri Jiva Goswamis as well as with Bhugarba and Lokarnath Goswami.
And these great devotees spoke to him encouragingly, reducing his feelings of loss.
Ramachandra Kaviraj and Shamananda Prabhu also joined Srinivas in Vraja on this occasion.
When he returned to Gouda, Srinivas joined in the festivities occasioning the anniversaries of the departure of Gadadara Das in Katwa.
Narahari in Srikhanda and Dujahari Das in Kanchanagiriya.
From there he went to Budhari village where Ramachandra Kaviraj and Govinda Kaviraj hosted him with great uplands.
Narottama Das Thakur had also left Vrindavan on Lokarnath Goswami's orders, returning to his home in Keturi.
On the full moon day of Phalgunam, he established the worship of six sets of deities in the temple.
Koranga, Vallabhikanta, Rajamohana, Shri Krishna, Radhakanta and Radharavana.
Srinivas Acharya performed the installation ceremonies of the first puja.
Janava Devi was also present at this great event.
After the festival, she went on to Vraja with her and Raj.
Upon her return, she met with Srinivas Acharya at Katwa and then went with him to spend some time in Jajigram.
Srinivas Acharya made another trip to Navadip
with Narottama and Ramachandra Kaviraj, performing the parikrama of the nine islands, each of which represents one of the limbs of devotional service.
When Raghunandan Thakur entered the Nitya Leela, Srinivas Acharya went to Shrikanta to help conduct the funeral festivals in his honor.
He returned with a heavy heart to Jajigram and from there went to see his disciples in Vanavishnupura.
He was received by the excited king and the other residents of the temple.
There, he received an order from Mahaprabhu himself in a dream to accept the hand of Gaurangapriya, the daughter of a certain Raghava Chakravarti.
Raghava and his wife, Mahadavi, had been searching for a suitable husband for their daughter, with no success.
They also received the order in a dream to give their daughter in marriage to Srinivasa.
As a result, Srinivasa married for a second time.
The pure devotee has no other objective in life than to fulfill the desires of the Supreme Lord.
They are thus ready to do anything if it pleases the Lord.
None of their activities has the slightest hint of material desire in it.
Srinivasa Acharya is the Avesha incarnation of Mahaprabhu himself, and his transcendental activities can only be described by someone who has received his special blessings.
Srinivasa Acharya Ki Jai!
